div.note: Lucy is speaking (i.e., “‘Mamma’, said Lucy, ‘papa has gone out to town’”). Note that Ruskin's first story begins with the father's absence. For the transportation John James Ruskin probably used to commute to his business in London, see Camberwell: London Commuter Transport.

note.p: “to go to town and then into the city and then to the docks” (MS I)—For the business center of London that had come to be called "the City", where John James Ruskin's counting house was located, see City of London: Billiter Street and the Premises of Ruskin, Telford, and Domecq. By going "to town", Mamma probably means simply entering the environs of London. For the docks, see City of London: The London Docks. By "town", Mamma might refer to Camberwell

“discourse” (MS I)—This comparatively sophisticated word choice, which Ruskin does not used idiomatically (to "get" the discourse "of silkworms"), occurs only twice in Edgeworth, Harry and Lucy Concluded; the word occurs more frequently in Barbauld, Evenings at Home.
